hero.title: Insurance Glossary
hero.description: Understanding insurance terminology is key to making informed decisions. Browse our comprehensive glossary of insurance terms organized by category.

iul.title: IUL - Indexed Universal Life
iul.description: Flexible permanent life insurance with cash value growth potential tied to market indexes, offering both protection and wealth accumulation.

terms.definition: A type of permanent life insurance that combines a death benefit with a cash value component. The cash value grows based on the performance of stock market indexes while providing downside protection.
The savings component of a permanent life insurance policy that accumulates over time. In IUL policies, cash value grows based on index performance with caps and floors.
The maximum interest rate your IUL cash value can earn in a given period, even if the linked index performs better. This limits upside potential but provides predictability.
The minimum interest rate your IUL cash value will earn, typically 0% or 1%. This protects your cash value from market losses, ensuring it won't decrease due to market downturns.
The amount paid to beneficiaries upon the insured's death. In IUL policies, the death benefit can be adjusted, and policy loans may reduce the benefit amount.
A loan taken against the cash value of an IUL policy. These loans typically don't require credit checks and accrue interest, but unpaid loans reduce the death benefit.
The ability to adjust premium payments in an IUL policy. You can increase, decrease, or skip premiums as long as there's enough cash value to cover policy charges.
How well a stock market index (like the S&P 500) performs over a specific period. IUL cash value growth is linked to index performance, subject to cap and floor rates.
A rider that keeps an IUL policy in force even if cash value is depleted, as long as minimum premiums are paid. This provides protection against policy lapse.
The cash value in an IUL policy grows without being taxed until withdrawal. This allows for compound growth over time without annual tax implications.
A fee charged if you cancel an IUL policy early. These charges typically decrease over time and are designed to encourage long-term policy ownership.
The cost of insurance deducted from the cash value in an IUL policy. This charge covers the death benefit and typically increases as you age.

aca.title: ACA â€“ Affordable Care Act
aca.description: Get comprehensive health coverage through the ACA Marketplace with premium tax credits and essential health benefits.

terms.definition: A federal law enacted in 2010 that provides access to affordable health insurance through the Health Insurance Marketplace. Also known as Obamacare.
A subsidy that helps lower monthly health insurance premiums for eligible individuals and families. Credits are based on income, family size, and the cost of coverage.
Ten categories of health services that all ACA plans must cover, including preventive care, emergency services, hospitalization, prescription drugs, and mental health services.

Categories that indicate how you and your insurance plan share costs: Bronze (60% coverage), Silver (70%), Gold (80%), and Platinum (90%). Higher tiers have higher premiums but lower out-of-pocket costs.
The annual period when you can enroll in or change your ACA health plan. Typically runs from November 1 to January 15 in most states.
A time outside of Open Enrollment when you can enroll in health insurance due to a qualifying life event, such as marriage, birth, loss of coverage, or moving.
A health condition you had before your coverage started. Under the ACA, insurance companies cannot deny coverage or charge more due to pre-existing conditions.
A service that helps individuals and families shop for and enroll in affordable health insurance. Also called the Exchange, it's available online, by phone, or in person.
Additional savings that reduce out-of-pocket costs for deductibles, copayments, and coinsurance. Available to Silver plan enrollees who qualify based on income.
A requirement to have health insurance or pay a penalty. While the federal penalty was eliminated in 2019, some states have their own individual mandates.
An insurance plan that meets ACA requirements and is certified by the Health Insurance Marketplace. These plans provide essential health benefits and consumer protections.
The percentage of total average costs for covered benefits that a plan will cover. For example, a plan with 80% actuarial value covers 80% of costs, while you pay 20%.

dentalVision.title: Dental & Vision
dentalVision.description: Affordable dental and vision insurance plans to help maintain your oral and eye health with coverage for exams, cleanings, and treatments.

terms.definition: The maximum amount your dental insurance will pay for covered services within a benefit year. Once reached, you're responsible for 100% of additional costs until the next benefit year.
A period of time you must wait before certain dental services are covered. Preventive care often has no waiting period, while major procedures may require 6-12 months.
Dental Health Maintenance Organization - A type of dental plan that requires you to see dentists within a specific network. Typically has lower premiums and no deductibles but less flexibility.
Dental Preferred Provider Organization - A type of dental plan that allows you to see any dentist but offers better benefits and lower costs when using in-network providers.
Insurance coverage for braces and other orthodontic treatments. Often has a separate lifetime maximum and waiting period, typically 12-24 months.
A fixed dollar amount your vision insurance provides for frames, lenses, or contact lenses. This allowance is typically provided annually or every 12-24 months.
A fixed amount you pay for a covered service, such as $10 for an eye exam. Copays are typically required at the time of service.
Your share of the cost of a covered service, calculated as a percentage. For example, if your plan has 20% coinsurance, you pay 20% of the allowed amount after meeting your deductible.
Services designed to prevent health problems, such as dental cleanings, exams, X-rays, and annual eye exams. These are often covered at 100% with no deductible.
A dentist, optometrist, or other provider who has agreed to provide services at negotiated rates with your insurance company. Using in-network providers typically costs less.
A provider who hasn't agreed to negotiated rates with your insurance. Using out-of-network providers typically costs more, and some plans may not cover these services.
The total amount your insurance will pay for certain services over your lifetime. Common for orthodontic coverage, typically ranging from $1,000 to $2,000.

finalExpense.title: Final Expense (Burial)
finalExpense.description: Affordable permanent life insurance designed to cover funeral costs, medical bills, and other final expenses, providing peace of mind for your loved ones.

terms.definition: A type of whole life insurance designed to cover end-of-life expenses such as funeral costs, burial or cremation, medical bills, and outstanding debts. Also called burial or funeral insurance.
A type of final expense policy that accepts applicants regardless of health conditions. These policies typically have waiting periods and may have higher premiums.
A type of final expense policy that requires answering a few health questions but no medical exam. These policies typically have shorter or no waiting periods compared to guaranteed acceptance.

A death benefit structure where if the insured dies within the first 2-3 years, beneficiaries receive a limited benefit (typically return of premiums plus interest) rather than the full death benefit.
A type of permanent life insurance that provides coverage for your entire life as long as premiums are paid. Final expense insurance is typically a form of whole life insurance.
A premium amount that never increases, regardless of age or health changes. Most final expense policies have fixed premiums that remain constant throughout the policy term.
The amount paid to beneficiaries upon the insured's death. Final expense policies typically have smaller death benefits ($5,000-$50,000) compared to traditional life insurance.
The person or entity designated to receive the death benefit from a life insurance policy. You can name multiple beneficiaries and specify how the benefit should be divided.
A feature that allows you to access a portion of the death benefit if you're diagnosed with a terminal illness. Also called living benefits, this can help cover medical expenses while you're alive.
The savings component of a whole life insurance policy that accumulates over time. You can borrow against or surrender the policy for its cash value, though this reduces the death benefit.
When a life insurance policy is terminated due to non-payment of premiums. Some policies have grace periods and may use cash value to pay premiums if available.
An option that provides a smaller death benefit without further premium payments if you stop paying premiums. This uses the cash value to purchase a paid-up policy.

hospitalIndemnity.title: Hospital Indemnity
hospitalIndemnity.description: Supplemental insurance that pays cash benefits directly to you when you're hospitalized, helping cover expenses not covered by your primary health insurance.

terms.definition: A type of supplemental insurance that pays fixed cash benefits (a set dollar amount per day) directly to you when you're hospitalized, regardless of other insurance coverage.
The fixed dollar amount paid per day of hospitalization in a hospital indemnity policy. Benefits are typically $100-$500 per day, paid directly to the policyholder.
The maximum number of days per hospitalization or per year that hospital indemnity benefits will be paid. Some plans have unlimited benefit periods.
Insurance designed to work alongside your primary health insurance to help cover additional costs. Hospital indemnity is a form of supplemental insurance.
Money paid directly to you (not to the hospital or provider) that you can use for any purpose. Hospital indemnity benefits are paid as cash benefits.
Hospital indemnity benefits for hospitalizations due to accidents, which are typically covered immediately without waiting periods, regardless of pre-existing conditions.
Hospital indemnity benefits for hospitalizations due to illness, which may have waiting periods (typically 30-90 days) before coverage begins.
An additional benefit some hospital indemnity plans offer for stays in the Intensive Care Unit. This may pay a higher daily benefit or a lump sum.
A benefit some hospital indemnity plans provide for emergency room visits, typically paying a fixed amount per visit regardless of whether you're admitted.
A benefit some hospital indemnity plans offer for outpatient surgical procedures, paying a fixed amount per procedure.
How multiple insurance policies work together. Hospital indemnity benefits are paid independently of your health insurance, so they don't coordinate or reduce based on other coverage.

A limitation that excludes coverage for conditions you had before the policy started. Some hospital indemnity plans exclude pre-existing conditions, while others may cover them after a waiting period.

shortTermMedical.title: Short Term Medical
shortTermMedical.description: Temporary health insurance coverage for gaps between major medical plans, offering quick enrollment and flexible terms.

terms.definition: Temporary health insurance that provides coverage for limited periods, typically 30 days to 12 months, with some plans allowing renewals up to 36 months. Designed to fill coverage gaps.
A period when you don't have health insurance coverage. Short-term medical is designed to fill these gaps, such as between jobs or while waiting for ACA enrollment.
The process of evaluating your health history to determine eligibility and premium rates. Short-term medical plans use medical underwriting and can deny coverage based on health conditions.

The ability to extend a short-term medical policy beyond its initial term. Renewals may be limited by state regulations and may be considered new policies, meaning conditions developed during the previous term could be excluded.
A limitation that excludes coverage for health conditions you had before the policy started. Most short-term medical plans exclude pre-existing conditions entirely.
Coverage restrictions that limit what services are covered or how much the plan will pay. Short-term medical plans typically have more limited benefits than ACA-compliant plans.
The maximum amount a short-term medical plan will pay for covered services within a benefit year. These maximums are typically lower than ACA plan limits.
The total amount a short-term medical plan will pay over your lifetime. These maximums are typically much lower than ACA plans, which don't have lifetime maximums for essential health benefits.
Services or conditions that are not covered by the insurance plan. Short-term medical plans typically exclude preventive care, maternity care, mental health services, and pre-existing conditions.
The ability to enroll in short-term medical coverage quickly, often within 24-48 hours of application approval. This makes STM ideal for immediate coverage needs.

Plans that don't meet Affordable Care Act requirements. Short-term medical plans are not ACA-compliant, meaning they don't have to cover essential health benefits or accept people with pre-existing conditions.
Temporary insurance coverage during life transitions, such as job changes, graduation, or waiting for employer benefits. Short-term medical is designed for transitional coverage needs.
